loans.use: to purchase a solar home system that will substitute the use of expensice candles with clean, durable and reliable energy

loans.name: Gloria Elsi

texts.es:
Gloria de 29 años de edad, madre soltera de tres hijos de 8,11 y 14 años de edad, se creció a lado de su madre quien le enseño mucho de los trabajos, junto a sus hermanas crecieron en las artesanías de hilo (elaboración de hamacas de seda y de poliseda), estudió hasta segundo grado en la escuela de la comunidad y ya no pudo seguir debido a las carencias económicas de la familia. De ella depende su madre,  sus tres hijos a quienes los tiene estudiando el nivel básico en el centro escolar de la comunidad, lo hace con grandes esfuerzos pues es madre soltera, su esposo se fue y los abandono.

Gloria se dedica a la elaboración de hamacas desde los doce años de edad cuando su madre le enseño a ella y a sus hermanas, hoy en día se encarga del aseo en la unidad de salud de su comunidad, trabaja de lunes a viernes de 7:00 am a 4:00 pm, por las tardes junto a su madre y a sus hijos ayuda a elaborar las hamacas para ir a venderlas los  fines de semana.

Solicita el préstamo para comprar de 200 libras de hilo de seda, valorado en $900.00, con lo que esperan elaborar muchas hamacas aprovechando la época de verano y navideña para salir a venderlas a la plaza. Gloria sueña con crecer en el negocio ya que vive a la orilla de la calle principal le facilita mucho  mostrar su producto que posteriormente vende en la comunidad, además espera construir su vivienda donde poder darle  una mejor comodidad a la familia.
texts.en:
Gloria, 29 years old, is a single mother of three children, ages 8, 11, and 14. She grew up at her mother's side, who taught her a lot of tasks. Along with her sisters, they grew up in the textile crafts (making silk and faux silk hammocks). She went up to the second grade in the community school and couldn't continue because of her family's economic struggles. Depending on her are her mother and her three children, who are students in the community primary school.  She manages with great effort because she is a single mother. Her husband went away and left her. 

Gloria has worked making hammocks since she was twelve years old when her mother taught her and her sisters how.  Today she is in charge of cleaning a health center in her community. She works from Monday to Friday from 7:00 am to 4:00 pm. In the afternoons, along with her mother and her children, she helps to make the hammocks to go and sell them on the weekends.  

She asks for a loan to purchase 200 pounds of silk thread, worth $900.00, with which she hopes to make many hammocks, taking advantage of the summer season and Christmas to go out and sell them in the plaza.  Gloria dreams of growing the business. Since they live on the edge of the main street, it helps a lot to show her product that she later sells in the community. In addition, she hopes to build a house where she can give her family more comfort.

loans.use: to purchase 200 pounds of silk thread.

loans.name: Isidra´s Group

texts.en: Isidra and Mariana live in a small community close to Tuxpan in Veracruz without electricity. Isidra sells food and snacks that she cooks. Her house serves as restaurant as well and she spends 3 candles a day to light room where she cooks and receives guests. She spends US$35 per month in candles, which represents 20% of her monthly income. With the solar home system Isidra will be able to cook and serve food until later at nights and increase her sales.  She will also feel safer at nights as the system provides better light.

loans.use: to purchase a solar home systema that will allow her to cook and serve clients for longer hours at her house-restaurant

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en: Yusuf is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, he would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yusuf can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. When asked about his goals, Yusuf expressed a desire to use the extra income from selling his maize at a later date to provide food and clothing for his family, and in the long run, to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Malama

texts.en: Malama is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Malama joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children Finehas, Samson and Jummala.  Before she became a Babban Gona member, Malama would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Malama can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.  Malama would like to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to make more money for herself and her family.

loans.use: to pay for children's school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Rahila Yakubu

texts.en: Rahila Yakubu is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Rahila Yakubu would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Rahila Yakubu can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked about her goals, Rahila Yakubu expressed a desire to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for her family, and in the long run, ensure her children: Manasseh, Tambaya and Laraba are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for her family, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Sa'ade

texts.en:
Sa'ade is a maize farmer from Chiroma village in Kaduna state. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Sa'ade would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for her immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Sa'ade can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Sa'ade, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for her family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for her family, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Ya'u

texts.en: Ya'u is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Ya'u joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Dashiru, Halisa and Binta.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ya'u would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to met his immediate cash needs for food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ya'u can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Ya'u  spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing for his family thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ali would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ali can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Like other Babban Gona members, Ali is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing

loans.name: Kalep

texts.en: Kalep is taking out another loan on Kiva! Kalep previously accessed an Rp 10.000.000 loan that he used to purchase green technology products to sell in his community. He came up with a new sales technique and loaned a cookstove to people to try for two or three days. He saw when they experienced using the stove first hand, they came back to buy. To help him continue operating his business, he is requesting another Rp 10.000.000 loan. He will use the loan to buy more stock of green technology products and provide solutions to his customers’ problems: difficult access to clean water, unaffordable LPG gas which make them to choose between three stone fire or kerosene stove, and frequent power cuts. Kalep is grateful for the support to increase earnings to cover his personal, household and business expenditures.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for his technology kiosk

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en:
In Kojwando A village in Ndhiwa, Kenya, Florence has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Florence is a friendly member of the community with two children. Florence lives with her family in a house made of concrete walls, a concrete floor, and an iron roof.

Kojwando A village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Kollo spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Florence’s family and the 50 other households using Kollo spring need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Florence has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Florence volunteered to be the promoter because she wants to help her community to have access to safe water to prevent water-borne diseases. There are also 4 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: namely Lilian, Margaret, Carolyne and Mary.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Florence’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Jenipher's Group

texts.en:
Jenipher is 50 years old, has 4 children, and lives in Pala Lower village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Pala Lower village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Kamin Agawo spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Jenipher, her family, and others may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Jenipher works as a subsistence farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Jenipher and other promoters in her community, including Loyce, Phoebe, Evans and Quinta, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Jenipher will encourage the community to treat their water with chlorine and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Jenipher wants to be a promoter because she believes that the dispenser will help them treat their water without having to buy the chlorine.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Jenipher’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
In Gakamira village in Kuria East, Kenya, Rose has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program. Rose is a friendly member of the community with 8 children. Rose lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, a dirt floor, and a grass roof.

Gakamira village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a local well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Rose’s community needs a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Rose has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage her community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Rose volunteered to be the promoter because she believes chlorine kills bacteria in water and makes it safe to drink. There are also 3 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Josephine, Samson, and Esther.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Rose’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Kehongo's Group

texts.en:
Kehongo lives in a home with mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof in Kwibancha South village in Kuria East, Kenya with his family that includes 8 children. The community of Kwibancha South collects their drinking water from a local well because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases often making Kwibancha South’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. Kwibancha South community will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Kehongo has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are 4 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Agnes, Jane, Miriam and Simion.

Kwibancha South community needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Samuel’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Jacob's community needs a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Jacob has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Jacob volunteered to be the promoter because he believes use of chlorine will help prevent water-borne diseases. There are also three other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Josephat, Jared, and Catherine.

Fransiscah is 45 years old, has 4 children, and lives in Pala village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Pala village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Pala hill borehole. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Fransiscah and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Franciscah works as a peasant farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Fransiscah and Melda (the other promoter in her community) need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Fransiscah will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Fransiscah wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine will kill germs, make water safe for drinking, and help us prevent waterborne diseases for a healthier community.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Fransiscah’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

Dina works as a subsistence farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Dina and other promoters in her community need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Dina will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Dina wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine will kill all the germs in the water making it safe to drink.

loans.name: Elisha's Group

texts.en:
Elisha is 52 years old, has 10 children, and lives in Misita village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Elisha works as a peasant farmer for a living. Where Elisha lives, his family and his community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from Gudu well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Misita village had a way to treat their water, they could improve the health of their community, keeping children at school and parents at work.

This is why Elisha and two other promoters, Edward and Agnes, are requesting a loan for chlorine dispensers on behalf of their communities. Elisha was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. He is not only representing his community on Kiva, but also volunteers his time to educate the people in Misita village on the importance of safe water, and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at Gudu well. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Elisha wants to be a promoter because he  believes that the chlorine will help the community to get safe water and have a healthy life due to the reduction of water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Elisha’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Ritchie Joie

texts.en: Ritchie is a 24-year old college graduate and lives in Bago City. She belongs to a family of 8. Her father is an auto mechanic, and her mother is a housemaid. Ritchie has 5 siblings. Three of her siblings already have their own family, while the rest are in high school and  elementary. Their total monthly family income of Php8,000.00 ($182) is barely enough to provide for their basic needs. This motivates Ritchie to find means to help the family have more income that's why she underwent the selection process of Bagosphere and successfully passed it to qualify for the 2-month training program that could lead to a call center job. Apart from helping her family, Ritchie also dreams to have a permanent and stable job.

loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get her a job paying about $270 monthly

texts.en:
Peter lives in a home with mud walls, a dirt floor and an iron roof in Gwikonge C village in Kuria East, Kenya with his family which includes 2 children. The community of Gwikonge C village collects their drinking water from a local water spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Gwikonge C’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerrycans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. Peter has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the dispenser and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their drinking water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are two other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Wankuru and Tobias.

Gwikonge C community needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispensers. Peter believes that the dispenser will help reduce water-borne diseases. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get her a job paying about $270 monthly

loans.name: Ryan Von Gerri

texts.en: Ryan Von is a 27-year old college undergraduate and lives in a rural village in Kabankalan City. He belongs to a family of 7. His father is a farmer, and his mother is a housewife. Ryan Von has 4 siblings still in school. Their total monthly family income of only Php 5,000.00 ($114) is not enough to provide for their basic needs. This motivates Ryan Von to find means to help the family have more income, and he's thankful that he successfully passed Bagosphere's selection process to qualify for the 2-month training program that could lead to a call center job --- that will, hopefully, lead them out of subsistence.

loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get him a job paying about $270 monthly

loans.name: James' Group

texts.en:
James is 41 years old, has 5 children, and lives in Itongo Central village in Kenya. James works as a commercial farmer for a living. Where James lives, his community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from a local spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Itongo Central community had a way to treat their drinking water, they could improve the health of their community, keeping children at school and parents at work.

This is why James is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of his community. James was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. He is not only representing his community on Kiva, but also volunteers his time to educate the people in Itongo Central village on the importance of safe water and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at their local water point. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. James wants to be a promoter because he believes that through the use of the chlorine dispenser, community members will be able to lead a healthy life because chlorine kills bacteria in water, so they will be free from water-borne diseases like typhoid.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that James’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Ana Marie

texts.en: Ana Marie is a 28-year old college undergraduate and lives in Bago City. She belongs to a family of 6. Her Father is not working anymore because of old age, and her mother is a housewife. Ana Marie has 3 siblings. Her eldest sister works as a domestic helper in Hongkong, while her two brothers already have their own family. Her sister in Hongkong provides Php15,000 ($341)per month, but this is not enough even for their basic needs. This pushed Ana Marie to undergo the selection process of Bagosphere hoping that the training could lead to a call center job.  Your generosity in funding her tuition will help Ana Marie better her life.

loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get her a job paying about $270 monthly

Daniel and other promoters in his community, including Esther and Tabitha, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Daniel will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Daniel wants to be a promoter because he believes that chlorine will kill all the germs found in the water making it safe for use by the community.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Daniel’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Bernalyn

texts.en: Bernalyn is a 21-year old high school graduate and lives in Pulupandan. She is married to Milo, who works as a security guard in Philippine Airlines in Manila. They have a 2-year old child . Their total monthly family income is only Php16,000.00 ($364). Bernalyn learned about the 2-month training program of Bagosphere that could lead to a call center job, and she saw this as an opportunity to help provide for her family's basic needs and then save some money for her child's education.

loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get her a job paying about $270 monthly

loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get her a job paying about $270 monthly

loans.name: Marie Therese

texts.en: Marie Therese returned to Haiti in 1987 to open a sewing business after several years' absence. She was very passionate and she did exactly what she loved to do. Despite the challenges in this sector, she stayed strong and always looked for new business strategies and opportunities. A few years later, the business started to gain potential customers. The business provides all kinds of fashionable dresses for women. The business is well known for adequately representing Haitian fashion design nationally and internationally. As the segment of market increases, the business needs to always stay up to date by acquiring three sewing machines, a generator, fabrics, and raw sewing materials to increase production. A loan from Zafen will result in a positive impact on the business’ financial performance.

loans.use: to purchase three sewing machines, a generator, fabrics, and sewing materials

loans.name: Anonymous

They have 3 children Thida (23), Sokheng(17), and Savata(15). The children are all  students. They need a solar system to save money on energy cost.

Their total monthly family income is only Php6,000.00 ($136). Noemi needs to help her spouse but didn't have the means until she learned about the 2-month training program of Bagosphere that could lead to a call center job. Now that she has passed Bagosphere's selection process, she needs your help to finance her tuition. Once Noemi starts earning, she can help provide her family's basic needs and then save some money for her child's education.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: A portion of Nkiruka's group 210,000 Naira loan will help a member to process and store palm oil products.

loans.name: Awad

texts.en: Awad is a 47 year-old-man from Baniswef. He is married with 6 sons and has been selling fruits and vegetables for five years but his monthly income is very low because his project is very small. So he decided to expand his project by a 5000 EPG loan from TADE to buy more fruits and vegetables like apples, bananas, kidney beans and zucchini.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables like apples, bananas, kidney beans and zucchini.

loans.name: Emad

texts.en: Emad is a 34-year-old man from Baniswef. He is married with one son and one daughter both in elementary school and he lives with his parents in the same house. His father is civil servant and makes very low income that doesn't cover his family's monthly expenses so Emad is the main breadwinner of the family. Three years ago, Emad started a cement store project in his village. During the last few months, Emad couldn't meet the increasing demands of his customers so he requested a 10,000 EPG loan from TADE to buy new kinds of gypsum and cement to meet the demands of his customers.

loans.use: To buy new kinds of gypsum and cement to meet the demands of his customers.

loans.name: Nageh

texts.en: Nageh is a 48 year-old-man from Baniswef. He is married with three school kids and works as a part time farmer with very low income due to his old age and bad health condition, as farming requires exhausting physical effort. He wishes he could increase his family's monthly income by starting a small grocery store business in a place he prepared in his house. So he requested a 5000 EPG loan to buy different kinds of fruits and vegetables such as apples, bananas, oranges, potatoes, onions, and tomatoes to start his small business.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of fruits and vegetables such as apples, bananas, oranges, potatoes, onions, and tomatoes.

loans.name: Chon

texts.en: Chon(58) and his wife live on a floating village in Tonlesap River, Cambodia. They fish for living and grow crops in dry season. They have 3 children Sri(19), Srun(11), Srorn(8). All his children are still in school except Sri who is in Korea to work as factory worker(domestic worker). At the floating village there is no electricity grid, so he wants to own a solar home system for a better living conditions and save money while it is also good for the environment.

loans.use: to buy a solar home system

location.town: Koh Tamov Village, Kampong Preahkorki Commune, Bor

loans.name: Gamal

texts.en: Gamal is a 33 year-old-man from Baniswef. He is married with three sons. Two of them are in elementary school. He sells fruits and vegetables in markets but the high transportation fees he has to pay affected his monthly income negatively. So he decided to start a grocery store business. Gamal rented a shop in a well-known place in his village and prepared it but the preparations were too expensive for him, so he requested a loan to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell in his new store.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables such as oranges, bananas, beans, and tomatoes.

loans.name: Noeurn

texts.en: Noeurn(38) lives in a floating Village in Kampong Chnang Province in Cambodia with his wife and 3 Children. They do fishing all year round and farm in dry season. Their children are Sonay(18), Vilay (16), and Maly(9). Sonay and Vilay are doing farming and fishing too and Maly is a student. Now they need to use a battery to supply their home with electricity but this is very expensive and unhealthy so they want to own a solar home system to save cost and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a solar home system

location.town: Koh Tamov Village, Kampong Preahkorki Commune, Bor

loans.name: Zakaria

texts.en: Zakaria is a 57 year-old-man from Baniswef. He is married with 6 sons and a daughter. He and two of his sons have been raising and selling poultry for three years as he couldn't work in farming due to his old age and his weak health condition. Zakaria's monthly income couldn’t cover his family's increasing monthly expenses so he requested a 2000 EPG to buy poultry such as chickens, ducks, and geese to expand his small project and improve his monthly's family income.

loans.use: To buy poultry such as chickens, ducks, and geese.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 29 year-old-man from Baniswef. He has three sons; the oldest is in elementary school. He lives with his mother and his younger brother in the same house and he is the only breadwinner of the family. He started a poultry project by a 5000 EPG loan from TADE and successfully repaid it on the due date. For months, Ahmad's brother has been looking for a job and couldn't find an available one. so Ahmad requested a 10,000 EPG loan to buy more poultry to expand his business and allow his brother to join him to his project.

loans.use: To buy more poultry such as ducks and chickens to expand his business and provide a job to his brother.

loans.name: Soad

texts.en: Soad is a 47 years old from Baniswef. She is married with four children in school. Her husband used to work as a part time farmer but he could not keep his job because of his old age and bad health condition, since farming requires hard physical effort. So Soad decided to start a small poultry project in her house. She prepared the roof of her house for the project and requested a 3000 EPG loan from TADE. Soad successfully repaid it on due date. Then she requested another 5000 EPG loan to expand her small business and successfully repaid it, as well.  For Soad the sky is not the limit since she requested a third 10,000 EPG loan to purchase more kinds of poultry such as doves, chickens, and geese.

loans.use: To purchase more kinds of poultry such as doves, chickens, and geese.

loans.name: Kamel

texts.en: Kamel is 26 years old from Baniswef. He is a graduate of the agricultural high school and has three younger sisters. His father is a part time farmer. Kamel can't find any job opportunity to help his aging father with the family income. So he decided to start a fattening project as he has studied fattening cattle in the agricultural high school and has enough knowledge about the best fattening methods. He prepared a suitable place in his house for the project and requested a 5000 EPG loan to buy a head of cattle to start his project. He believes this project is going to be very successful and will change his life.

loans.use: To buy a head of cattle for fattening in his house.

loans.name: Bình

texts.en:
Mrs. Bình works in agriculture, raising marine aquaculture. Bình has been involved in this business for more than 10 years.

Bình is 37 years old, and she is married with two children. She lives in Hoang Hoa district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

This is Bình first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

The main hardship that Bình faces in her life is not having a clean water syterm. She is requesting a loan to buy a clean water filter, and install a clean water system.

In the future, Bình hopes to maintain a successful business, for her children to find good jobs, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

loans.use: to buy a clean water filter, and install a clean water system

loans.name: Lại

texts.en:
Lại works in agriculture, farming poultry and cattle. She has been involved in this business for more than 10 years.

Lại is 45 years old, and she is married with four children. She lives in Hoang Hoa district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

This is Lại's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

One of the most critical difficulties that concerns her is not having a water tank. She is requesting a loan to buy a water tank, and install a clean water system.

In the future, Lại hopes to maintain a successful business, for her children to find good jobs, and to build a new house.

loans.use: to buy a water tank and install a clean water system

loans.name: Salomat

texts.en:
Salomat is a businesswoman. She was born in 1962 – in the northern part of Tajikistan. She lives in a rural area. She is married. She has three children. Her husband works as cattle breeding man. 

Salomat started her business of buying and selling daily products. She works hard. She sells domestic goods like buckets, stationary goods, snack foods, etc. Also she sells seasonal products such as New Year's toys. She works in order to improve her family’s standard of living. 

Salomat wants to enlarge her business. She needs financial support for buying new goods.

loans.use: To buy industrious goods such as buckets, stationary goods, etc.to increase inventory

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is a widow with four children who do not attend school, and she also looks after two grandchildren. Sarah lives in a rented house with access to electricity but she does not have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses are food and rent. 

Sarah operates a food stall in the market, selling retail. She has been doing this for nine years and works seven days a week. She generates additional income through selling sweet bananas. Her challenges include transportation and seasonality. 

She has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT- SACCO to buy sweet potatoes, oranges, tomatoes, cassava and sweet bananas to sell. 

Her dream is to build a house on her land.

loans.use: To buy bags of sweet potatoes, cassava, onoins, tomatoes and oranges

loans.name: Mạnh

texts.en:
Mạnh works in agriculture, farming poultry and cattle. She is 53 years old and she is married, with two children. Mạnh lives in Hoang Hoa district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2009, Mạnh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. She has successfully repaid six loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She has been involved in this business for more than ten years.

One of the most critical difficulties that concerns Manh is not having a hygienic latrine. She is requesting a loan to purchase sand, cement, and brick to build a toilet.

With her business profit, Mạnh hopes to build a new house, to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

loans.use: to purchase sand, cement, and brick to build a  toilet.

loans.name: Matilde

texts.en: Matilde is 42 years old and lives in Naga, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, island of Mindanao, Philippines. She is married with 2 dependent children now of school age. Matilde has been engaged in real estate dealing and brokerage for 5 years. She earns approximately 20,000 PHP each month from this type of business. This helps her family a lot in sustaining their needs, even though she also receives support from her husband who is a seaman. Matilde has requested a loan to be used for paying her daughter's tuition fees; her daughter is presently studying at one of the universities in Cebu City. She has been a member of PMPC for almost 1 year. Matilde wants to save more in the cooperative for her children's educational needs in the near future.

loans.use: To be used for paying her daughter's tuition fees

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is 64 years old and lives in Santa Cruz, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is married with two adult children. Naomi is a servant of God, a female pastor in one of the religious congregations in the country. She receives a monthly honorarium of at least PHP 15,000 each month for doing this type of ministerial work.

Naomi has been a member of PMPC for one year. She has applied for a 25,000 PHP loan through PMPC to be used to buy additional sacks of cement, paint, tiles and home accessories for completion of their newly-constructed house.

In the future, Naomi hopes that all her family and congregation will become members of and participate in the cooperative’s activities.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of cement, paint, tiles and home accessories to finish her house

loans.name: Melchor

texts.en:
Melchor is a fisherman, from Concepcion, Iloilo. He is 44 years old, married, and has five children. The eldest is 19 and the youngest is 10 years old. Melchor has been in the fishing business for more than seven years, now. This is the source of his income.

Melchor is asking for a loan. He intends to use it to buy fishing materials, like nets, hooks and others, floaters, and lead weights. With this loan, he will be able to improve his catch, and that will enable him to sell more fish in the market. In the future, he hopes to make his fishing business a success. Moreover, he wants to save money for his children's schooling.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials like nets, hooks, floaters, and lead weights.

loans.name: Yonnie

texts.en:
Yonnie is a 58-year-old married woman and a mother of four grown up children from Concepcion, Iloilo. She has been engaged in a fishing business with her husband for more than 20 years now. This is the source of their income.

Yonnie is asking for a loan to pay for the repair of the fishing boat and to buy additional piglets to raise. This loan will help Yonnie and her husband in improving their catch, thus giving them more fish to sell in the market.

In the future, Yonnie hopes of making her business a success. Moreover, she wants to save money for the reinvestment into the same venture.

loans.use: to pay for the repair of the fishing boat and to buy additional piglets to raise.

loans.name: Serah

texts.en:
Serah is 35 years. She is married to John and together they have been blessed with five children aged between 15 and seven years old.She is a farmer, and she has been in this business for the last 17 years, earning a monthly income of KES 10,000.

She has requested for her second loan from VisionFund Kenya of KES 30,000 which she will use to buy fertilizers and maize seedlings, as well as pay laborers. She will use the anticipated profit to pay school fees for her children.

Serah's hopes and dreams for the future are to grow her business and be stable in her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and maize seedlings, as well as pay laborers

loans.name: Amparo Pilar

texts.es:
En el cantón 24 De Mayo se reúne el Grupo De Crédito Nuevos Horizontes De 24 de Mayo, este lugar es conocido por sus paisajes hermosos y por su gente trabajadora dedicada a la agricultura y cría de animales. 
En este lugar vive la señora Amparo, tiene 32 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre y tiene un hijo de 13 años el cual estudia en colegio. Su marido es comerciante.
Doña Amparo para salir adelante y para que no le falte nada a su hijo se dedica al comercio, ella tiene una tienda de víveres en su casa,  allí vende todo tipo de productos como arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, helados, etc. Trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, su hijo le ayudan en su tienda cuando esta desocupado, a pesar de que solo tiene un año con su negocio lo tiene bien surtido y esto le ha dado mayor clientela con el paso de los días.
Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir más su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, embutidos, detergentes y otros productos de primera necesidad. Está desde el inicio en el Grupo De Crédito  y le gusta porque con los créditos ella sale adelante. Sus metas son seguir aumentando su tienda.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Nuevos Horizontes de 24 de Mayo” (New Horizons of May 24) meets in the canton of May 24. This place is known for its beautiful landscapes and its hardworking people who engage in agriculture and raising animals.

Sra. Amparo lives in this place. She is 32 years old, in a common-law relationship, and has a 13-year-old child in high school. Her husband is a merchant.

Doña Amparo works in retail so that she can get ahead and because she doesn’t want her son to lack anything. She has a provisions store in her house where she sells all types of products such as rice, sugar, oil, detergents, ice cream, and other items. Amparo works every day from 6:00 A.M. to 8:00 P.M., and sometimes much later. Her son helps at the store when he is not busy. Despite having this business only a year, Amparo keeps it well-stocked and has built up a large clientele, which helps the days pass by.

This loan will be used to acquire more inventory for her store. She will buy rice, sugar, sausages, detergents, and other basic necessity products. Amparo has been with her Communal Bank from the beginning and enjoys being a member because the loans have helped her get ahead. Her goals include continuing to expand her store.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, sausages, detergents, and other basic necessity products.

loans.name: Jovencia

texts.en: Jovencia is 55 years old and is a married woman. She has had a bakery business in the Philippines for 3 years. Jovencia requested a 7000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients for her bakery. In the future, Jovencia would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her bakery business.

loans.name: Urcesia

texts.en:
Urcesia is 63 years old and has five children. She is a married woman.

Urcesia is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 6,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Urcesia has been in this business for two years now and has borrowed two times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Urcesia would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Junabelle

texts.en:
As a married mother of three children, Junabelle works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from tricycle passengers.  Junabelle is borrowing PHP 50,000 through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell to customers.

Junabelle has been sustaining her business activities through her past 16 loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Kyekumburwa Development Network Group

texts.en: Alice is a member of Kyekumburwa Development Network, living in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is engaged in selling secondhand clothes plus farming for additional income. She faces challenges of lack of enough capital and the changes in tastes and preferences of customers based on the ongoing designs. Besides that, she has great hopes of expanding her business to new areas. Alice needs a loan to buy more clothes to sell during this festive season.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell during this festive season.

loans.name: Phung

texts.en: Phung would like to take a further loan to buy more hair care products to sell from her store. Phung's previous loan enabled her to increase her sales and earn a higher income to support her family. She hopes that another loan will assist her in increasing the size of her business, attract new customers and increase sales. She also hopes that through the loan she can increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy hair care products to sell from her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for the upcoming semester fees and buy some books that he needs.

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es:
Ana una joven de 22 años de edad que heredo el negocio familiar de venta de pijamas y ropa interior el cual quiere proyectar con su visión joven y emprendedora.
Trabaja diariamente para pagar sus estudios, apoyar en su hogar y cualquier moneda que le queda la guarda en una alcancía que dice mi mayor sueño mi casa propia.
Esta entusiasta y trabajadora joven quiere solicitar un crédito para la compra de nueva colección de pijamas y ropa interior, el motivo es la época de diciembre, quiere sorprender a sus clientes con diseños frescos e innovadores, creando en ellos fidelidad para continuar proyectando su negocio hacia un futuro y estabilidad económica.
texts.en:
Ana is a young girl of 22 who inherited the family business selling pajamas and undergarments and she wants to apply her young and enterprising vision to it.  

She works every day to pay for her education and support her household and whatever money is left over she keeps in a piggy bank; she tells us, "my greatest dream is to have my own house."

This enthusiastic and hardworking young person wants to request a loan to buy a new collection of pajamas and undergarments because it is December and she wants to surprise her customers with fresh and innovative designs, which will make them loyal so she can keep guiding her business toward the future and financial stability.

loans.use: to buy a new collection of pajamas and undergarments.

loans.name: Enas

texts.en: Enas is a 20-year-old single lady. She chose to go to Al Yarmouk University, one of the public universities, for it is close to where she lives so she can save on transportation fees, and the university fees are somehow affordable. Enas is majoring in Arabic Literature for her passion is learning more about the language, and her hope is to work as a teacher to transfer her passion to the new generation of students. In her free time between lectures, Enas goes to work at the university’s library to make some money while applying her hobby in reading more books. But now Enas is applying for an education loan to help her cover the rest of her next semester fees.

loans.use: To pay for the rest of her next semester fees.

loans.name: Kholoud

texts.en:
Kholoud is the mother of two children. She was a housewife until her husband retired from his work. 

They realized that the retirement salary will not be enough for them to support the children, so her husband started working as a taxi driver while Kholoud started selling blankets at home to those who live in the neighborhood. She did this business last year at this time of the year and found it a helpful one since it covered their needs in winter. 

Now Kholoud is requesting a loan to do the business again and bring more blankets to sell which will help them make more income to cover their expenses.

loans.use: To buy more blankets to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay the school fees and pay his graduation fees.

loans.name: Raghad

texts.en: Raghad is a 19-year-old single lady living with her family in Zarqa. Raghad has always loved art, which made it easier on her when it came to choosing a major to study in the university. Raghad registered to major in art teaching and she is now in her second year. She has two sisters.  One of them studied chemistry, the other Arabic language. Raghad is requesting an educational loan that can help her pay for her next semester fees at the university so she can proceed in achieving her goal.

loans.use: To pay for her next semester fees at the university.

loans.name: Sura

texts.en:
Sura is a 21-year-old single lady living with her family in Irbid. Sura goes to one of the biggest public universities to study computer science for her passion in computers. She is now in her third year. 

Besides being a student, Sura is a very hard-working young lady. To afford paying for her schooling fees, she works as a private tutor to school students teaching mathematics and English language. The money she makes helps her in paying her university fees. 

But now Sura is requesting a loan to pay for some training courses that she wants to take to improve her skills in programming and make a better use of her time while she is still a student.

loans.use: To pay for some training courses that she wants to take to improve her skills in programming

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay the next semester's fees, so he can continue with his studies in Banking and Finance.

loans.name: Majed

texts.en:
Majed is a 47-year-old married man, who used to work in a sweets shop and gained a lot of experience there. 

Majed used the experience and opened a small sweet shop where he is making limited kinds of sweets because he doesn’t have all the ingredients or the required machine to make some. As he had to close the shop at 12 noon after selling all the sweets he had, this has also affected his business.

Majed is applying for a loan to buy more machines and more ingredients to make new kinds of sweets so that he can have a collection and keep his store open during daytime.

loans.use: To pay for more machines and more ingredients to make new kinds of sweets

loans.name: Khadeejeh

texts.en: Khadija is a 31-year-old single lady. She is a hardworking lady who has always been supporting her family. She has a brother studying medicine abroad who is depending on his family to support his educational fees. Over a period of time, the family went through two deaths, her father’s and her youngest brother, which affected the family emotionally and financially. When her brother decided to come back to the country and stop his education and find a job to help the family, Khadija forbid him to do so and encouraged his to continue with his studies and decided to do whatever she could to continue supporting her brother and family. She started a small home-based business selling home products and some used clothing items to the neighborhood, which is helping her make some money that she can transfer to her brother believing that she is investing in him for the future. Now Khadija is requesting a loan to increase the quantity she has of clothes and more kitchen ware to increase her income.

loans.use: to increase the quantity of clothes and  kitchen ware to increase her income.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for his upcoming semester fees .

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine .

loans.name: Amjad

texts.en:
Amjad is a 23-year-old single lady. After she got her diploma degree, she opened a small clothing store in Southern Ghour close to where she lives in order to be able to support herself and live a decent life. 

Because of the high rate of birth in that area, Amjad chose to concentrate on selling children's clothes and made a small section for women's clothes. She started very small, buying clothes from a wholesale market and selling them at home. Then she moved to an independent store where she took the photo. 

Now Amjad wants to add to the women's section, selling accessories that go with the clothes. So she decided to apply for a loan that will allow her to buy a big order of accessories to sell at a low price to attract more people to her shop.

loans.use: To pay for a big order of accessories at a low price.

loans.name: Maria Fabiola

texts.es:
María nació en Pujilí una parroquia del Cantón Latacunga en la República del Ecuador. Pujilí es muy conocido por sus tradiciones y folklor y es conocida como Emporio Musical. María tiene 21 años de edad, actualmente vive arrendando junto con sus hermanos alrededor de dos años.
María logró terminar la primaria y la secundaria pero por falta de recursos económicos y por falta de oportunidades tuvo que dejar de estudiar y deslindarse de sus padres para poder salir adelante junto a sus hermanos. Ha sido para ella muy satisfactorio el poder ayudar a sus hermanos en todos los gastos de la casa y ser un gran apoyo en las actividades del hogar. 
Se le hace un poco difícil el cuidar de sus hermanos y a la vez dedicarse a su pequeño negocio, María se dedica al comercio de productos naturales Herbalife, y en estos últimos meses se ha dado cuenta de que su demanda ha crecido. Por lo que ahora solicita un crpedito para poder mejorar un poco el lugar donde vive, y poder invertir en más mercadería que le ayudara a mejor su vida y la de sus hermanos.
texts.en:
Maria was born in Pujili in the region of Latacunga, Ecuador.  Pujili is very well known for its traditions and folklore as well as its music.  Maria is 21 years old, and has lived with her brothers for about two years.  

Maria completed primary and secondary school, however due to a lack of resources and opportunities she was forced to drop out of school and separate from her parents in order to be able to progress forward with her brothers.  It has been pleasing to her to be able to help her brothers with the household expenses and responsibilities.  

It has been somewhat difficult to help take care of her brothers and at the same time dedicate herself to her small business of selling Herbalife products, for which she has noticed recently that there is high demand.  She is requesting this loan in order to be able to continue improving her home and invest in more merchandise that helps her improve her life and that of her brothers.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to sell in order to increase income and better her families living situation

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get him a job paying about $270 monthly

loans.name: Oktaviana

texts.en:
A loan of Rp. 10.000.000 helps Oktaviana to introduce simple, life-saving technologies such as solar lamps, water filters and clean cookstoves to her community. 

Oktaviana’s dream was to be a nurse but she couldn't afford the university degree due to financial difficulties. She and her husband run a mobile delivery business, bringing supplies such as toiletries and groceries to villages in Tambolaka using an old pick-up truck. They supply small shops who do not have access to transport to restock their product from the central market located far away in town. With this connection to remote villages in the area she is confident to sell technologies while selling wholesale products. When people ask about kerosene, she can explain about the health and cost benefits of replacing kerosene lamps with solar powered lights.                                                                                                                               
 
Oktaviana will use the loan to buy stock and grow her business. She is excited about Kopernik’s training program to learn about these new technologies, better promote them to her customers and improve her general business skills.

loans.use: To introduce simple, life-saving technologies such as solar lamps, water filters and clean cookstoves to her community

loans.name: Leslie

texts.en: Leslie is an 18-year old college undergraduate and lives in La Carlota City. She is a single parent with 1 child aged 1-year and 6 months old. Leslie is living with her parents. Her father is a carpenter and her mother is a housewife. Their total monthly family income is only Php6,000.00 ($136). Leslie needs to help her family but didn't have the means until she learned about the 2-month training program of Bagosphere that could lead to a call center job. Now that she has passed Bagosphere's selection process, she needs your help to finance her tuition. Once Leslie starts earning, she can help provide her family's basic needs and her child's education.

loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get her a job paying about $270 monthly

loans.name: Gayratjon

texts.ru: Гайратджон  житель села Чашмасор. Ему 24 года. Он живёт в месте с отцом. С детства он занимается животноводством.  Гайратджон  продолжает отцовское дело.  Гайратджон  хочет купить корову, но для этого у него не хватает собственных средств. Он подал заявку на кредит в МДО Арванд. Он надеется на положительный результат и заранее благодарит за помощь.
texts.en: Gayratjon is a resident of Chashmasor village. He is 24 years old. He lives with his father. He has been practicing animal husbandry since he was young. Gayratjon continues his father's profession. Gayratjon wants to buy a cow but he does not have enough money. He submitted an application for a loan through MDO Arvand. He relies on a positive outcome and thanks you in advance for the assistance.

loans.use: to buy a cow.

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.en: Alejandrina lives in Hueyapan with her teenage son. Alejandrina's husband lives in another country working hard so that his family can have a better life. She also works every day selling fruits and vegetables in the market. Alejandrina has been saving some of the money she makes to build a proper home. She has been saving for the last year to build a room so that her son can have his own room. Now that he is not that little, it is more difficult to share the same bedroom. She now needs a loan to finish paying for the materials and complete the home improvement. Since she does not have a formal job and no way to prove her income, she does not have access to credit from other institutions. Alejandrina is really looking forward to giving her son her own space. She will receive supervision visits from certified technicians to make sure the construction meets all the quality and safety standards. Alejandrina knows that this can only be achieved trough hard work and sacrifice.

loans.use: to buy materials to properly build a bedroom for her son
